title: Error: Couldn't resolve version spec %s: %s
body:
First of all, thank you very much for very useful application!

Now I got an error in nodeist@0.8.2 in Windows 8.1.
I have installed node with version 4.4.7 with nodist.

When I command `node` in the directory, then I got an error `Sorry, there's a problem with nodist. Couldn't resolve version spec %s: %s >=4.0.0 <7.0.0 improper constraint: >=4.0.0 <7.0.0`.

The directory have package.json file which includes key `"engines": {"node": ">=4.0.0 <7.0.0"}`, it might make problem.
When I removed the line `"engines": {"node": ">=4.0.0 <7.0.0"}`, then the command `node` works well.

Since the progress bar is a cosmetic feature and not essential to the operation of nodist I'll leave fixing why the response event isn't happening to someone who cares.

More important is that nodist actually works.
Fixes: #139

title: Compatibility with nodenv (nodist for OS-X/Linux)
body:
[nodenv](https://github.com/nodenv/nodenv) is doing the same thing that nodist does but for OS-X/Linux.

As our teams consists of Windows, OS-X and Linux users we would like to work with both tools in the same projects.

Unfortunately nodist and nodenv use the same file name `.node-version` but different notations.

Nodenv: `4.4.4`
Nodist: `v4.4.4`

This pull request adds the missing `v` when reading in the `.node-version` file so that nodist won't crash if the v is missing.

Please let me know what you think about it

title: Handle version spec component omissions

Do you think it would look better if there was a space before the version for `nodist dist` output?  Now it looks crowded:

```
nodev5.4.0

```

Thanks for your tool!

title: Treat io.js versions as node versions, since the version spectrum is a continuum
body:
I threw out a whole lot of ugly code to get back simple version numbers instead of the whole mess with converting back and forth between `nodev5.2.0` and `5.2.0`.

Io.js is now treated as a node version, since that's made possible by the continuous version spectrum.

Let me know what you think :)

title: Version ranges in global/local/env + automatic target script version detection (based on package.json)
body:
This enables the shim to inspect the parent directories of the script to be executed by node and search for a package.json in order to pick a node version that matches to its `engines` field. It also allows the specification of version ranges inside global/local/env version specs (see #90 ).

This is better than `.node-version` files, because those are based on the working directory you're in, whereas this version detection mechanism is based on the target directory. This rules out the need to globally switch versions before using global tools installed via `npm -g`, it would also allow having multiple npm instances in the PATH e.g. as `npm2` and `npm3`, if they exposed an `engines` field in their package.json.

Something that's up for discussion is the order of application of the different version detection mechanisms. The current order of application is: target script, env, directory, global.

A problem I see are testing tools like `mocha`, that are installed globally: if they expose an engines field, this is what's gonna be used. However, the actual package being tested might depend on a different, more restrictive node version in its engines field, e.g. mocha works with both node 4 and 5, but my library only works with 4 -- then node 5 will be used, because nodist's target script inspection doesn't know about my library :/

Note: This depends on #110

title: Installer does not default to correct/preferred machine architecture
body:
When you use the official installer on a 64-bit machine, the installer does **not** default to installing 64-bit builds on Node.js as I would hope for it to.  Furthermore, that fact is not made obvious to the user during installation unless they stop to expand the "Node.js Architecture" tree node in the Components list:

![image](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/417751/11172403/a318aa1e-8bcc-11e5-968b-7d9a3b4dabdd.png)

When I did expand that tree node, I was surprised that it showed a default selecttion of `x86` rather than a default that matched my machine's architecture:

![image](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/417751/11172408/c1b19148-8bcc-11e5-9f7d-d5ec5a00025c.png)

I would prefer that the installer either:
- **(a)** default to the correct/preferred machine architecture based on the system (i.e. `x64` on a 64-bit system, otherwise `x86`); _**OR**_
- **(b)** at least show the components tree node in its expanded state (the 2nd screenshot above) so that the user can plainly see that it is always defaulting to `x86` architecture rather than matching the system's.

title: Uninstaller should revert changes to `.npmrc` if feasible
body:
I ran into a lot of confusing after installing Nodist via the official *.exe installer and then uninstalling it because it had updated my NPM `prefix` configuration to point of Nodist's installation directory (I believe this occurs on Nodist's first run...?).

However, when Nodist is uninstalled, it does not revert that change to the NPM `prefix` configuration.

Ideally, at least if _some_ version of `npm` is still available in the `PATH`, I would prefer that the Uninstaller would revert that `prefix` value to avoid such confusion.

e.g. something like this [untested] Batch script:

``` batch
call :delete_npmrc_prefix

:delete_npmrc_prefix
setlocal EnableDelayedExpansion
where npm >NUL 2>&1
set EXIT_CODE=%ERRORLEVEL%
if %EXIT_NODE% NEQ 0 (
  endlocal & exit /B %EXIT_CODE%
)

set NPM_PREFIX=
for /f "usebackq tokens=*" %%c in (`npm config get prefix`) do (
  set NPM_PREFIX=%%c
)
if "!NPM_PREFIX!" == "{{NodistInstallDirectoryValueRetrievedFromSomewhere}}" (
  npm config delete prefix
  set EXIT_CODE=%ERRORLEVEL%
)

endlocal & exit /b %EXIT_CODE%
```

title: node.exe cannot be found after using the official nodist installer
body:
I just installed nodist on Windows 7 this afternoon using the very new "official installer" executable.  After I used it to install a few Node versions/builds, nodist runs into an path separators issue when actually trying to facilitate their usage:

P.S. This is using `cmd.exe` as the terminal/shell:

```
> nodist 0.12
nodev0.12.7

> node -v
Sorry, there's a problem with nodist.
Error:  exec: "C:\\Program Files (x86)\\Nodist/v-x64/nodev0.12.7/node.exe": file
 does not exist

> nodist 4
nodev4.2.2

> node -v
Sorry, there's a problem with nodist.
Error:  exec: "C:\\Program Files (x86)\\Nodist/v-x64/nodev4.2.2/node.exe": file
does not exist

> nodist 5
nodev5.0.0

> node -v
Sorry, there's a problem with nodist.
Error:  exec: "C:\\Program Files (x86)\\Nodist/v-x64/nodev5.0.0/node.exe": file
does not exist
```

title: Upgrade for 0.7.0 Official Windows Installer
body:
This is still a work in progress but I wanted to stub the new pull request.

The new version comes with a lot of features that I think can really help nodist into the future.

I have implemented a build system using the NSIS (Null Soft Scriptables Installer System).

I have gotten the build script producing a working installer.

This includes the code quality adjustments made as well. I know this will change a bit about how nodist is installed, used, released and built. So for that I figured it was best to get this pull request submitted and start working on some testing.

@marcelklehr I hope you are still with me on these changes.

I wont get a chance to do some more testing until Monday. Once I get there I will prepare this pull request for a merge.

Thanks

title: Ability to version control NPM
body:
Okay,

So one of the issues I have been having with nodist is being able to version npm. Sometimes the upgrades from the packaged version wont work. Or you want to test against a specific version.

My point is. It would be nice to be able to switch versions of NPM as easily as node. I am going to submit a separate PR against this.

Just stubbing this issue so I can work on it.

title: Print URLs being used
body:
I think like NPM used to do it might be a good idea to print the URLs being used when installing new versions of software.

I think this would be a good idea to allow the user to verify where the files are coming from. I also think this would be a good idea if a compromised version of nodist were to be distributed around the internet.

Just a thought.

title: Verify binary sum on download
Problem with 4.1.2 as of 10-05-2015
body:
Hi,

I just ran the following and am seeing some strangeness.

```
C:\Users\Mac>nodist 0.12.0
nodev0.12.0

C:\Users\Mac>node -v
v0.12.0

C:\Users\Mac>nodist selfupdate
Installing latest stable version...
nodev4.0.0
Update dependencies...
mkdirp@0.3.5 node_modules\mkdirp
request@2.9.203 node_modules\request
vows@0.9.0-rc3 node_modules\vows
├── diff@1.2.2
├── eyes@0.1.8
└── glob@4.3.5 (inherits@2.0.1, inflight@1.0.4, once@1.3.2, minimatch@2.0.10)

C:\Users\Mac>node -v
v4.0.0

C:\Users\Mac>nodist latest
nodev4.1.2

C:\Users\Mac>node -v
Sorry, there's a problem with nodist.
Error:  fork/exec \nodist/v/nodev4.1.2/node.exe: %1 is not a valid Win32 applica
tion.
```

Any idea what can be done here?

Just to investigate I went here: https://nodejs.org/dist/v4.1.2/win-x64/ and downloaded the `node.exe` file and then placed it in `C:\nodist\bin\node.exe` and renamed the existing to `node-old.exe` and then I get.

```
C:\nodist\bin>node -v
v4.1.2
```

So is it possible nodist is downloading the wrong file?

title: Does not work with Node 4.0.0
body: Gets a 404 error when doing an install of node 4.0.0

title: fetch executables via https
body:
Downloads through nodejs.org no longer work as nodejs.org now blocks HTTP and only allows HTTPS.
As a result, the "node.exe"-files that are downloaded is not a binary at all, but the HTML-content of the redirect page.

title: [WIP] Move precommitted node modules and add installation script
body:
This scarily looking PR does the following
- commit 1 renames `node_modules` in to `.node_modules` in root and `./bin` folders (`git mv`)
- remaining commits update gitignore, README and add an install script for bash (I'll try to come up with equivalent bat)

Since after cloning there'll be no node_modules directly available in the repo, the user will have to copy `.node_modules` to `node_modules`. This may seem wasteful and overcomplicated but IMO this is much better solution. Right now, after you clone git repo and do `nodist selfupdate` or `npm install -g npm`, suddenly you have hundreds of files marked as modified by git, which is annoying, slows down operations in the nodist folder, and makes it harder to contribute :) Also it makes it harder to recover from npm update failure - this is addressed in the install script, that should be able to fix this kind of problem. After this PR, npm and nodist deps are gitignored, so when they get updated, git diff shows no changes.

Looking forward to the comments.

if you want to move the files yourself instead of inspecting the huge commit, just do

```
git mv node_modules .node_modules
git mv bin/node_modules bin/.node_modules
git commit -a -m 'move files'
```

I tested `install.sh` quite thoroughly. The script can be run multiple times without any bad side-effects.

body:
With the release today of node version 4.0.0, I tried installing with nodist and got:

```> nodist 4.0
Couldn't fetch 4.0.0: HTTP 404.
Sorry.

```

Looking at the install directory, it looks like they removed the node.exe file from the root of the release version and moved it into separate win_x64 and win_x86 directories.
```

title: escape npm prefix path
body: If your `NODIST_PREFIX` contains a space (e.g. `C:\Program Files\nodist`) it will install your modules to `C:\Program\node_modules`

title: Uninstall doesn't discuss restoring `npm set prefix %NODIST_PREFIX%\bin`
body: Is the correct uninstall procedure to `npm config delete prefix`?  If so, I can PR this into place.

title: setx copies the current user's PATH into the system PATH
body:
For example, imagine the following environment variables:

**System** PATH = `C:\Windows`
Bob's **User** PATH = `C:\Users\Bob`

After running `setx /M PATH "C:\nodist;%PATH%"`
**System** PATH = `C:\nodist;C:\Windows;C:\Users\Bob`

In a command prompt the `PATH` command returns `C:\nodist;C:\Windows;C:\Users\Bob;C:\Users\Bob`

Another user, Alice, logs in.
Alice's **User** PATH = `C:\Users\Alice`
On a command prompt the `PATH` command returns `C:\nodist;C:\Windows;C:\Users\Bob;C:\Users\Alice`

Bob has a duplicate path in his `PATH` variable, and Alice has Bob's paths in her `PATH` variable.

title: Possible installation bug
body:
In the installation directives the line 6 states `npm config set prefix %NODIST_PREFIX%\bin`. However, if `NODIST_PREFIX` happens to have a space in it like `setx /M NODIST_PREFIX "C:\Program Files\nodist"` then npm will use `npm config set prefix C:\Program` which is not the intended path.

Maybe change the directive for `npm config set prefix "%NODIST_PREFIX%\bin"` to avoid possible issues.

title: Issue with setting node version
body:
I have installed nvm under the path:
**C:/Program Files/nvm**

After installing I ran the following command to install latest version of node:
**nvm install latest all**

I then ran the following command to set the node version I wanted to use:
**nvm use v0.10.34**

It showed the following error message
![error](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/5508006/5540016/8032eae0-8aed-11e4-8d7d-0832b4cfc426.png)

From the error message I think the issue is that the file path to nvm/node contains space i.e. _the space in the between "Program Files" of the file path where I have installed them_. 

Running the following command also threw a similar error:
![error1](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/5508006/5540075/133c47c8-8aee-11e4-81a0-7160a70c29f5.PNG)

I presume the file paths cannot handle spaces between them. A simple fix on this would be great.

title: Bash Script Fixes and Batch Script Modifications
body:
I hadn't really intended to make so many changes to the batch script, but an hour or so in, and this is where I found myself. That being said, if you'd like to accept some but not all of these changes, just let me know which parts you'd like me to revert. Anyways, I suppose it might help if I explain the reasoning for my modifications:
- **Variable Expansion/Case Sensitivity** - These changes were made in order to allow the script to still understand when the user specifies args in an unexpected way. (ex: `nodist "USE" "0.11.12"` - dumb, I know)
- **Self-Update Block Modifications** - I may have misunderstood something when I made these changes, so feel free to correct me if I'm wrong: In the original script, cmd was used to execute npm and nodist, but it do so with the unproven assumption that npm and nodist could both found on the user's `PATH`. This would fail in any cases where the user executed nodist using its filepath, and didn't have the bin folder on their `PATH`. On that assumption, I changed the this section so that all scripts are executed with their absolute filepath.
- **NPMRC Attribute Checks** - I'm probably the only person anal enough to do this, but to avoid having to stare at 20-30 dot files/folders every time I go to my HOME folder, I hide any new dot file that gets added. (and toggle visibility on the rare occasions that I need to get in there) Unfortunately, this causes npm to error out when it tries to access the hidden `.npmrc` file. In order to prevent this error, I added logic to the script to check for any attributes that would cause issues, remove them, and reapply them after npm finishes changing the user's configuration.
- **ERRORLEVEL** - This was only partially necessary in cases where the script should abort execution should one of the steps fail. (selfupdate for instance) Nonetheless, I went ahead and added error checking any time the script executes an action capable of failing.
- **:: -> REM** - Comments written using a blank label (`::`) have the potential to cause issues during execution. These issues most often arise in scripts that execute commands in blocks like this one, so I took some liberties and changed these pre-emptively. You can read a bit more on this in [this StackOverflow answer](http://stackoverflow.com/questions/12407800/which-comment-style-should-i-use-in-batch-files) and find some detailed information, including example code [on this site](http://www.robvanderwoude.com/comments.php).
- **NODIST_PREFIX** - I try to keep my defined environment variables to a minimum when possible. (at least as far as persistent environment variables go) Since the `NODIST_PREFIX` can easily be derived at the time of execution, I've gone ahead and had to script do so when it finds the prefix undefined.
- **NODIST_FORK_LEVEL** - This bit is probably pointless in this case, (pretty sure I was just fucking around by this point) but it's something I usually add whenever I write a self-executing batch script. Since the environment variables are localized to the script instance, each recursive execution of the script will increment the fork level by 1, and once the child script stops and execution is returned to the parent, the level returns to its original value. In its current form, this wont prevent any infinite recursion bug from occurring, but should one appear, would help to track and debug it.

You'll find a few annotations in comments in spots I wasn't sure about. (For instance: Why is `nodist add` executed twice? Is the second time just for the purpose of extracting the version number? (if so, I assume it returns immediately when it finds that noejs version already installed)

Lastly, I noticed open issue #63. I had originally intended to also include a shell script with my changes, but by the time I finished the changes to the batch script, I was pretty much over the whole thing. Still, I rewrote the script to a one-liner passing execution through the the batch script, which should hopefully resolve the issue until a shell script gets written. AS far as I know, which and sed are both included in every popular distribution of cygwin/msys, so there shouldn't be any issues with incompatiblities.

title: Write out version spec that's being used, to make version errors more intuitive.
`selfupdate` doesn't work under Git Bash/msysGit
body:
While looking into why `nodist selfupdate` was not working for me, I discovered that files: `nodist\bin\nodist` (sh) and `nodist\bin\nodist.cmd` contain different logic.

For example, if I run `nodist selfupdate` under Git Bash, rather than a vanilla Windows Command Prompt (CMD.exe), the entire `nodist.cmd` file is skipped and `nodist` gets executed immediately. So in this case, `selfupdate`, gets passed to `nodist\cli.js`, and it believes I'm trying to set the global Node version to "selfupdate", like you would with "stable" or "latest".

This errors with the message:

```
Version spec didn't match any available version.
Sorry.
```

If I write out the spec that's being used (https://github.com/marcelklehr/nodist/pull/64):

``` js
nodist/lib/versions.js
...
if(!v) return cb(new Error('Version spec, "' + version_spec + '",  didn\'t match any available version'));
```

...it comes out as

```
Version spec, "selfupdate",  didn't match any available version.
Sorry.
```

Could the logic in `nodist.cmd` be either;
- ported into `nodist\bin\nodist`,
- or ported into `nodist\cli.js`?

I believe this would allow `selfupdate` to work, as intended, under Git Bash.

title: Update to npm 1.4.24 does not execute update script correctly
body:
See https://github.com/npm/npm/issues/6045. Here are the relevant parts:

<hr>

@UltCombo:

I've just tried to update npm from version 1.4.23 (running `npm update npm -g`), at some point in the process it executes the following CLI command:

```
"C:\nodist\bin\\node_modules\npm\bin\npm-cli.js" update npm -g
```

Thing is, Windows simply ignores the `#!/usr/bin/env node` directive and opens the file with the given extension (`.js`)'s associated default executable (in my case, Sublime Text 3), so the update just breaks there.

I believe it should be easy to fix, simply prefix the command with `node`, so it would end up with:

```
node "path/to/npm-cli.js" update npm -g
```

<hr>

@othiym23:

This is _definitely_ a nodist issue and not an npm one – npm rewrites the shebangs itself and also won't invoke itself without a node binary on the command line. Ideally this command would be invoked via node.cmd, so it's possible there's some kind of PATH hijinx going on. Either way, this isn't an npm problem.

title: Global NPM packages
body:
I'm a little confused as to how NPM global packages are supposed to work. NPM packages installed with the global -g flag seem to get put in the node_modules folder in the active Node version folder.
`.../nodist/v/0.10.31/bower.cmd`

As these folders aren't added to the PATH variable there is no way to actually call any of your standard tools like bower or grunt without manually adding them to your PATH. Is this the expected behaviour when installing global packages? As far as I can tell, there is a global NPM version and I would have expected global dependencies to be installed in `nodist/node_modules` or similar.
